title: Hurricane Dorian Heads North, Whips Carolinas
text:
WILMINGTON, N.C.—A weakened Hurricane Dorian trudged up the East Coast on Thursday, causing flooding, tornadoes and power outages and threatening to pummel North Carolina overnight.

Earlier this week, the slow-moving storm demolished towns and left at least 30 people dead in the Bahamas, according to the Associated Press. Yet for the most part in the U.S., the storm so far has been a menace but not the catastrophe once feared.

Still, Dorian disrupted daily life for many residents along the southern half of the Eastern Seaboard for a week. Coastal communities from Palm Beach, Fla., to Virginia Beach, Va., were evacuated, and schools and many businesses closed.

But the preparations proved unnecessary in many cases. People in Georgia and South Carolina joined Floridians in breathing a sigh of relief Thursday that the hurricane didn’t turn into the worst-case scenario.

By early Friday, the once-Category 5 Dorian was a Category 1 hurricane, producing winds of 90 miles an hour, down from a peak of 185 mph. The storm was about 55 miles east of Wilmington, N.C., and moving northeast up the coast at 15 mph, the National Hurricane Center said. Hurricane-force winds extended 60 miles out from the storm center.

Forecasters said Dorian would likely continue to weaken, but warned of the potential for life-threatening storm surges and powerful winds on the North Carolina coast and portions of southeast Virginia and the southern Chesapeake Bay.

Low-lying streets in Charleston’s historic downtown and elsewhere in South Carolina’s Lowcountry flooded Thursday as a storm surge and lashing rains swept through the area. Transformers blew out. Schools, government offices and almost all businesses closed.

Kelsey Myers surveys the damage in her front yard in Summerville, S.C., after the storm swept through. Photo: Mic Smith/Associated Press

But in the end, Charleston and Beaufort fared better than expected because of a fortunate confluence of winds, tides and the time Dorian approached, said South Carolina Gov. Henry McMaster.

“The water did not get as deep as anticipated, although there is still plenty of it,” Mr. McMaster said. He lifted evacuation orders in several of the state’s southern counties.

Peter Hill and his wife, Lauren Hill, ventured out of their downtown Charleston apartment after the storm passed to check the damage. They said they found little of note, and were even able to walk along East Battery Street along the city’s harbor, which frequently floods.

Mr. Hill, a 38-year-old U.K. native, said there were inconveniences associated with Dorian, such as the lack of power, but it was just like a normal storm in England. “I was frankly let down a bit,” said Mr. Hill, who noted that a rainstorm during their wedding in Charleston caused more flooding.

The northern coast of South Carolina saw some flooding late Thursday but less damage than Georgetown Mayor Brendon M. Barber Sr. said he had expected.

At one point, the city’s 9,200 customers were without power, but most was restored by late afternoon. Mayor Barber said emergency-management officials had fretted that the confluence of high tide and the arrival of the storm would cause major flooding and potential loss of life, but initial reports showed no major issues.

Mr. Barber said he hosted a Facebook Live prayer vigil on Wednesday with local pastors, asking that their waterfront city be spared. “We dodged a bullet,” he said. “Our prayers were answered.”

More than 6,900 people had taken refuge in shelters in Florida, Georgia and the Carolinas, said Charley English, national emergency management liaison at the American Red Cross. And about 260,000 homes and businesses were without power in North Carolina and South Carolina, according to poweroutage.us, which tracks data from multiple carriers.

As the storm moved slowly toward North Carolina, authorities issued a tornado warning Thursday along the coast of the Carolinas. North Carolina Gov. Roy Cooper said at least one tornado touched down and left a 10-mile stretch of destruction. The coastal town of Emerald Isle, N.C., also reported a tornado that badly damaged an RV park.

The states of Florida and North Carolina reported a total of four deaths, all of them involving men who died getting ready for the hurricane.

Gov. Cooper said Dorian continued to be a strong and dangerous storm. It was predicted to dump as much as 7 inches of rain on the coast. Forecasters expected a storm surge could raise water levels on the North Carolina coast by 4 to 7 feet above normal tide. Inland flooding was possible through the weekend, Mr. Cooper said.

“Even when the sun is shining, rivers rise and flooding can occur,” Mr. Cooper added.

Dozens of school systems closed in North Carolina ahead of the storm as far inland as Raleigh, more than two hours’ drive from the coast. In coastal Wilmington, businesses shut and downtown hotels and restaurants placed sandbags by doors and windows in expectation that the Cape Fear River would flood streets, as it did during Hurricane Florence last year.

Early-voting sites closed in the eastern counties of North Carolina’s Ninth Congressional District, which has a closely watched do-over election Sept. 10.

A tornado hit Emerald Isle, N.C., as Hurricane Dorian moved up the East Coast. Photo: Tom Copeland/Associated Press

In the Outer Banks of North Carolina, forecasters in Nags Head said there still was uncertainty about whether Dorian would make landfall. But they said the Outer Banks’ long chain of barrier islands would be subject to heavy rain, flooding and the possible washout of N.C. Highway 12, a main artery that frequently is impassable after storms.

Vidant Health’s Outer Banks Hospital treated patients in its emergency room midday Thursday but none in its beds as the staff made final storm preparations, said Vidant officials. “We’re ready to go,” said nurse Tony Buzzacco, director of the hospital’s emergency services. “We’re at that point that we’re just waiting for it now.”

Storm shutters were secured over the hospital’s windows Thursday. The hospital, a joint venture between Vidant and Chesapeake Regional Healthcare, was built to withstand sustained 150-mph winds and had stockpiled food, fuel and medical supplies during Dorian’s slow approach.

—Melanie Evans and Erin Ailworth contributed to this article.
